And thirdly on brand, clearly you emphasize the power of the Vodafone brand, clearly there are competitors taking a multi-brand strategy. If you could just remind us of your philosophy about multi-brand, including potentially the use of different brands on the fixed side.

Yes, let me start and then I leave the market. So I take the brand, market share and outlook. I think dogmatism is wrong in business, and therefore my philosophy for the brand is that the brand – the Vodafone brand is a fantastic brand and we need to leverage on it as much as possible. However, pragmatically there are situations where you might want to have a second brand. And this is what we are already having, and Michel may comment about that.

Tactical use of second brands, tactical use of sub-brands associated to the main brand, but in a loose way. I mean, I think it's fair. I mean, and again, as long as we are clear that this is a tactical use of something else, it's fine. So we are not – and I think Michel maybe you want to say a little bit more of what we are doing and you link this to Germany and Spain.

So on brand, I guess that we are quite pragmatic. Of course, we have one major brand, which is a Vodafone. In some markets we do have, let's say, additional brands, whether it's in fixed, for example, in Italy with Tele2, or in Germany where we have introduced a second brand for prepaid offers in order to match tariff expectation from some of our customers. Or we also leverage partnerships with MVNOs, so for an wholesale type of agreement when we don't want to develop ourself a new brand because it will be too expensive to do it. So quite pragmatic, and we have some projects in some other countries that you will see in the next quarters.

As far as market shares are concerned, you have probably seen that in Germany this quarter we have stabilized our market share, so where there's a revenue performance that we have delivered. And I should say that in terms of serving this revenue growth quarter-on-quarter, we are the highest in the market, so which has allowed us to stabilize our market share. In Spain we are still losing a little bit of market share, mainly to MVNOs and to, let's say, you go. So as you know, there's this fourth player which is building up in the market, so which means that, let's say, you can expect the main players to lose slightly market share for the time being and then probably stabilizing.

In terms of confidence on the outlook, I think if you go back two years ago when we last did the strategy update, we were sort of looking straight into the precipice of the global downturn. I think things have improved a lot since then. Clearly things are not totally clear, but I think that is one major factor in here.

I think the second one is probably that data four years ago was a concept that we strongly believed in but did not have a lot of revenue. Two years ago it was starting to show its mettle. And now we are sitting with a 5 billion revenue stream, a clear appetite from customers' devices that really are taking off, and just I think a lot more confidence on the data front that this is real and this is a big opportunity for us. So you put those together and we thought it would be helpful to go out with some numbers to show where we are aiming to get to.
Yes, let's go a little bit back there. Yes?

Yes, hello. It's a James Ratzer from New Street Research. I had two questions, please. First one's on slide 40 you show a multiplicity of connected devices split between high-end smartphones, entry-price handsets and mobile connectivity. I was wondering if you could say today which one of those is the most significant for data revenue growth, which one is the least significant, and then over the three year guidance which one is the most significant, least significant, so if there's a sequence of changing mix within that.

And the second question I had please was regarding tax. We're in an environment when governments are starting to kind of scrutinize their tax receipts a little bit more closely. Could you please confirm your medium-term guidance on the group tax rate and also the long-term viability of the way you hold Verizon Wireless, whether you think the kind of tax structuring there can be maintained? Thank you.

Yes, let me take the first one. In absolute, clearly smartphones, the most important thing and mobile internet is the most important thing. But I'm not sure I would look at things the way you propose, because when you talk about multiplicity of connected devices, you are talking about sometimes the same customer. And I am not so sure a MiFi dongle that you keep in your car that serves in a Wi-Fi environment your car, is it a dongle, is it – so what is it? And where you use it at home it's a replacement for the dongle in your car, in your PC.

So there is a – what we said is we need to go into a new world where you have a relationship with the household or with an enterprise, and the multiplicity of accounts, and the multiplicity of devices hooked into that relation, a little bit like it happens already with companies. And that's the way we look at it. And that's why we have started investing a while ago in IT systems, in building in all the capabilities beyond the network that will enable that.

And that's why I am now going back to the earlier question, we have more confidence about the data revenue growth because we see that this is happening in a major way. So when I said Vodafone will be in the hands, in the car, in the house and in the office of our customers, it's really a multiplicity of situations, but the relationship will be the most important one. I'm not sure we will go at a detailed level of by device. Think about in Germany we announced we launched this DSL with IPTV with digital terrestrial channels integrated. It's a product in the home and it does certain things that, at the end of the day, it's the relationship which matters.
Peter, want to do tax?
I don't know. Should we pass it to Steve?

Yes, I mean, the tax is obviously getting a lot of focus at the moment, so I think we understand in terms of the state of government finances and the economics at the moment that that is understandable. It's interesting, we're seeing some countries, this being one of them, where the focus is on actually getting corporate tax rates down to increase competitiveness. We've seen one or two other countries which have done small, but sort of targeted tax increases, particularly in the telco sector. So it's something which obviously we are monitoring very, very carefully. We said that sort of mid-20s as an effective tax rate for the group we think is where we should be for the medium term. At the moment we don't have any reason to believe anything different to that. And in terms of the last part of your question, on the U.S. we are very comfortable with the structure there, so that is fine.
Yes?

Steve Malcolm from Evolution. I'll go for a couple, please. I'm interested in your comments on scale, Vittorio, and sort of the fact that you're trying to make a difference for your customers in terms of costs. It's kind of hard to see that because, as you mentioned, your yields tend to be a little bit higher. Your data pricing is rarely lower than anyone else's. Your margins are no higher. So how should we think about the way you leverage your scale? For a given level of subsidy can you put more value in, should we see that in more volumes in terms of new customers going forwards in market share take? Should we expect higher margins going forward to your competitors? Could you give us a couple of tangible examples of where that scale is sort of being brought to bear in customer numbers and from your shareholders' perspective at the moment?

And then on top of that, sort of different to that, on roaming, can you give us an idea what's happening to price and volume on roaming at the moment, reflective of solid, better, I guess, economic environment in Europe? Thanks.

Yes, I think you see the advantage of scale in the cash flow mostly. And in the fact that we have been able to support big growth with stable CapEx. You see it in – and you will see it more I think in the ability to see ARPU increase. We now have three European markets where we have ARPU increase in absolute terms, and that will be again a reflection of the ability to attract the customers on the higher bundle packages because the service is good. And again, I don't think it's by coincidence that the three markets where we have the ARPU increase are Germany, U.K. and Netherlands which is where we have been working in that direction. So this is where you will see it more and more.

Subsidies, quite frankly, are a function of competition. I mean, I wish I could see in all markets subsidies balanced to the profitability, and we will do our best to make sure that we go there. But again, we don't want to lose commercial traction. So subsidies, in a way, are more a function of competition.
On – you want to add anything?
So on roaming?
No, on the first point.

On the first point, let's say just as far as subsidies are concerned, I get that more and more we are trying really to manage our subsidies in a profitable manner, meaning that we, let's say I look at subsidies based on the price plans that are then subscribed by the customers and we take also into account the behaviors through each device, because we know that a specific type of device can unlock additional revenue and so can allow us to manage a little bit more the subsidies in one way or the other. So we are more and more, let's say, a management of our subsidies in a profitable manner.

On the roaming, maybe the second question, so on this quarter we have a slight decrease of traffic in Europe in roaming. In fact, it's a clear reflect of the macroeconomic situation, meaning that roaming is increasing in Northern Europe, but decreasing, and meaning in Spain, in Southern Europe, that's for voice. On data we still see a strong potential to unlock roaming in the next coming quarters as, let's say, of course data roaming is much smaller than what we are experiencing in voice today. We have more or less 40 million customers roaming on voice and we have, let's say, 4 to 5 roaming on data.
Should we go there? Justin [Credit Suisse] and then we come back and then – yes, and then through you we'll come back.

Thanks. Yes, just a couple of questions. No guidance on operating profit at the moment, which is understandable, but do you think we should be thinking about some sort of iPhone effect on Verizon Wireless margins next year, perhaps in the first half of next calendar year, whether we need to think about that at all.
Secondly, I just wonder if you could make it more simple on your CapEx message. Are we talking about European CapEx to sales going up, and how much?

Just thirdly, on sort of commercial questions, when TI launched their equivalent of your per second pricing in Italy, it cannibalized their base for longer than most of us thought. Are you managing the cannibalization effects in Italy or is it too soon to tell? And then in the U.K., are you benefiting a bit from Everything Everywhere taking their eye off the ball a bit? Thank you.

On Verizon Wireless, I would not comment on the guidance of another company that we don't manage based on commercial assumptions that are not in our control. So I would like to ask you ask them the question. On CapEx, maybe, Michel, you want to be a little bit more specific on CapEx in Europe?

I guess that on CapEx in Europe plus the group functions last year we were around 11%. So we were slightly over 10%, and what Vittorio was saying is that we are quite pragmatic, so we should remain in that range. Again, we are look at CapEx where we see that there is profitable growth, and as you have seen on data, we are gaining market share.

On commercial, so on Italy, that's true that we have seen a strong cannibalization within Telecom Italia and that has been reflected in their revenue figures through the pricing that they have tested during the summer. As you have seen, we have not suffered this same effect; we have made some tactical moves during the summer in order just to protect our base, mainly on mix and text and voice. We have changed recently our pricing structure in prepaid and postpaid. And we are very happy with the first results of that, 1.5 million customers have already subscribed to our new options on prepaid. And we have seen a regain of traction in terms of gross adds, so which means that not only not of cannibalization, but we even increased our market share in terms of the gross adds additions in the past few weeks. So we are quite happy with the results of those new pricing.

In the U.K., so as you can expect, you have seen that is a result that we have published. I guess it's our highest net adds in the past three years at 281,000 additional customers that we have captured in the quarter coming from the different operators. We have port positive vis-à-vis all the operators, meaning Orange too on one side and, of course, O2 on the other side. So, yes, we are capturing customers from those different base through thanks, let's say, to all the measures which have been taken in terms of distribution. Now iPhone, portfolio of device, new pricing, so I guess that was a bunch of new things which have allowed us to regain traction.

But I would say in Italy and the U.K. we are competing well. I mean, it's doing the right things. I'm not sure exactly what's going on in Italy, why Telecom Italia is behaving like this. But we are confident that we have solid offers in the U.K. ARPU going up was good news for us because it means that what we have been doing is right.
You have been waiting for long, apologies.

Thank you, Karen Egan from RBS. You showed on slide 41 that the increase in ARPU for smartphone users is to a large extent matched by the higher commercial cost of acquiring them. Does that explain why in Europe the EBITDA is still falling by 5% organically although revenues are improving and cost reduction is on track? And does it also explain why your three year guidance at the EBITDA level is a bit more vague than your revenue guidance?

And on the same vein, for full year EBITDA, margins were down 170 basis points in the first half, can you be a little bit more specific about what you are expecting in the second half, in particular it seems many analysts are expecting flat year-on-year margins in the second half? Do you think that's reasonable?
Why don't we start from the last part and then we take the kind of smartphone economics question.

Yes, we said at the start of the year that we expected for the whole of this year on average a significant reduction in the – reduction of the margin, which was 220 basis points last year. So, I mean, roughly 100 basis points, I guess, out of that. So 170 first half, mathematically, you're right, we'd need to be a down 0.25% or so in the second half of the year. As Michel has mentioned earlier, part of this is the commercial investment which we kicked off in the second half of last year and therefore is on a comparable basis for the two second halves, but it was not on a comparable basis for the two first halves. So directionally, that is where we all aim to get to in the second half.

On smartphone economics, I think you're pointing to the right chart, maybe getting to a little bit of an early conclusion. The chart indicates mins and max, so you can be on one end or at the other end or anywhere in between. As I said in my earlier answer, the more choice we have with smartphones, the more Android, the more Mobile 7, the more RIM, the more whatever choice we have, the better it is, because that gives the opportunity to improve the yield. If you look at cases like the U.S., you have seen probably AT&T's margin going down in the earlier phase of the introduction of smartphones and then going up. So the yield management and the commercial choice which is good for the customers will be good also for us.
Michel, do you have?

No, I guess that we have always said that there are two factors which are influencing our EBITDA decrease that you are referring to. First is revenue, of course, because we are still declining in terms of revenue, and the second is A&R due to the fact that we are investing ahead of the pack in order to push our smartphones in the base. As you have seen, our A&R is increasing by 10% year-on-year, let's say, H1 on H1, so which was there in order to push our smartphones, but the profitability of our smartphone in terms of incremental EBIT, we have shown at different occasions that it was the same as with the legacy phones. So we just have an upfront cost which is slightly higher.
Yes, here. You've been waiting for a while.

Thanks. It's Mark James from Liberum. Remuneration incentives and the metrics that you measure, you mentioned that you sort of changed the metrics that you measure to align them more closely with the changes in strategy. Can you elaborate on that in terms of what metrics you're using going forward and what targets are being served?

Absolutely. So what we did, we introduced in the yearly incentives relative competitive performance, which is a blend of revenues, profits and brand or NPS, whatever is the kind of metric, relative to the in-market competitors or the European or the worldwide. So at every level we have introduced that in the remuneration of people. And I have to say it has been incredibly powerful to see how people immediately focus, yes, on the budget, but also on the competitive performance.

We are now – we have increased the ownership at the Executive Committee level, so we have gone up quite a bit last year. We are now increasing ownership at the levels below us, and we will if – as I assume the board will approve, have a more similar system which would be mirrored below the top – whatever, 20, 30 people. So we really want to cover the top 250, 240 people with similar roles, with different clear – clearly different numbers, but similar roles, so that also the long-term part of the rewards is totally aligned to shareholders' interest both short and long-term.
Yes?

Thanks. It's Paul Marsch from Berenberg. Most analysts and investors seem to deduct about 25 to 30 pence for the capital gains tax theoretical liability in the event of an exit from Verizon Wireless. Now, the message today from you seems to be that the outlook for that relationship is to stay on board and reap the benefit of future dividends. An exit seems to be quite remote. Is that because there is no tax efficient exit from Verizon Wireless at the moment, or maybe there is, but Verizon doesn't find that option appealing?
Do you want to take the?

Yes. I mean, there are two, three points. The first is that as we are positioned today, as and when we do start to receive dividends, those will be tax free. And with the tax structure we have in place we also get other benefits from that. So the sort of status quo has a pretty good tax position. An outright sale, as you refer to, has a significant capital gains tax element to it.

There are some other options about the splits and things like that which are very complicated. They may be able to be done in a more tax-efficient way, but there are lots of operational, consent and other issues, and, frankly, at the end of the day, what it's still talking about a minority position without dividend rights. So whether it actually is value creating is very, very debatable.
But I think I can say that we as management and the board, we keep our mind open, as I said in my presentation, and we continue to assess options, because we have to.
Could I follow on with one more question? On use of proceeds from disposals, are you constrained in any way by your credit status – credit rating?

We're not constrained. I mean, we've said that we target a low A; we're on a split rating at the moment, we're on either a 2.3 or thereabouts multiple of EBITDA. So we're clearly at sort of one end of a range rather than the other end of the range. And I think in the medium-term that's really where the board wants to stay. Does it mean in the short-term we can go outside of it? We could do. But the intent would be to come back into that range fairly soon.
Thanks.
Yes?

Yes, it's Emmet Kelly at Merrill Lynch. Just three quick questions, please. The first one is on your Supermobile presentation. You gave a target for smartphone penetration within your base of around 35%, but didn't really talk about any data card penetration in the future. I guess at the moment, you're kind of giving preference to smartphones over data cards because data cards use so much capacity. However, going forward – correct me if I'm wrong, I guess the launch of LTE is probably the tipping point there, because LTE the pipe is so much bigger and the speeds are so much better. With Verizon Wireless launching LTE over the few weeks, if you were to see them really blowing the lights in terms of very, very strong data card take-up and seeing a very strong acceleration in revenue growth from data cards, would you consider going early on LTE, because up until now you've kind of talked about HSPA+ then MIMO and maybe LTE in 2012? So would you maybe like a going early in LTE?

The second question is again on Supermobile. You talked a little bit about best network; if you look at the U.S. and if you go to New York or if you're in Boston, everywhere you go you see Verizon Wireless advertising their best network message. And I think network perception in the States is very, very important at the moment and there's obviously a big gap in the network perception between Verizon and AT&T, for example. You showed a slide that suggests that you've got a better network quality here in Europe at the moment. Do you think you can extend that gap against competitors if you rollout MIMO and LTE? And also, do you think you're getting that message across to the subscribers through advertising at the moment and is this something you're looking to do going forward?

And then just the last question is on emerging markets. When you gave your full year results, you talked about a pretty big free cash flow swing at the big EM business – I think it was India, Turkey, Ghana and Qatar. Are you running ahead of schedule on that free cash flow swing after announcing the results today? Thanks.

Yes, the first question is almost a philosophical question. We're not against data cards of course. We just need to manage. As I said, it's a huge world; it's a world of people who use 500, 600, 700 per month doing mostly emails and PowerPoint, and a world of people who watch movies like I did two nights ago, but just they do it every night.

So it's a wide thing. The important thing is to yield manage commercially and technically and to basically make sure – I think in one of our countries we had... what was the percentage of the kind of 2% of people taking 26% of traffic or something like that – just streaming. Already today we are a big streaming network, already today the single largest application is that one. So it's just a matter of managing it. It's not a matter of saying we de-emphasize or we don't like it. And therefore, pricing is very important, and I'm a great fan of that.

LTE is part of it. Quite frankly, we are agnostic because as a customer I don't care, as long as I can get my own uninterrupted video for 39 minutes or 1 hour, I don't care whether it's HSPA+. Then it depends the capital efficiency and the technological efficiency choice. Where we can continue to increase, we increase, where we need to move, we move. But again, we are not likely – Verizon in a way was constrained because it's end of life for CDMA. For us it's not the case. So we will look at it. We are launching 1,500 sites in Germany and we will continue to evolve our network the way Steve will advise us to do.

On the best network advertising, we have it in Greece, we have it in the U.K. with the Sure Signal thing. It's a bit of a market by market thing. It depends on the market conditions. It depends can we really be structurally always much better than the main competitor. I think we can be slightly ahead of them but I doubt that we can with all the surface team that I have, I don't think we can really beat structurally by a large amount in the long-term serious players. Can we be significantly better than everybody else other than the main competitor? Answer yes. And so this is going to be – and which is why the polarization in the world of data, I am convinced is already happening. In emerging markets, cash flow?
Slightly ahead on Turkey and temporarily ahead on India, but probably will even itself out by the end of the year just because the import restriction issue. So overall, just slightly ahead.
Yes. One there. One there. Okay.

Hi there. Ottavio Adorisio from Société Générale. I have three follow-up questions actually that were already asked but I would like to have a bit more color. The first one is on bill shock. Now looking at slide 19, you're proposing £25 for 500 megabytes. I'm a happy Vodafone customer actually. At the moment I pay £5. So what's your assumption of customer churn when it's going to be presented to a 500% increase? And how your competitors – because for instance in Italy while TI went increasing pricing for voice, you were a net beneficiary. How churn can actually perform on the subsidiary where actually you're going to increase, especially in the markets where Three present, because it looks as though Three is going the other way, actually decreasing prices?

The second one is on the outlook. Now, the positions are moving pieces for EBIT, therefore I just want to have a quite precise answer. For your outlook for EBIT or operating profits, adjusted operating profits for the yearend, you have to achieve flat EBITDA margins. Is that consistent with your guidance or not?

And the third one is on you basically compare your EBITDA margins for H1 against the full year, you present today with a 50 basis points improvements. But if you remember well, and probably my memory has to double check, you're actually talking about last year that headline EBITDA margins were down 220 basis points, but adjusted was only 190 basis points. Therefore it looks that the 170 basis points you present today is just the same trend. Thanks.

Yes. let me take the pricing question. I think you're looking only at half of the picture. When people get one of these – I mean, if you ask my wife how much she pays for SMS, she doesn't know, how much she pays for minutes, she doesn't know, how much she pays for – she knows how much she pays per month. And how to go up. And this bundling of data and voice pricing is what we are absolutely pushing because voice as a service will not exist one day. I mean, we will not even talk about voice as a separate service. There will be a variety of services and you pay for your connection. So voice revenues will go down, data revenues will go up. Our exercise is to make sure that the total is higher than before.

And therefore, the type of thinking that you just illustrated does not take place in the shops. If you go into the shops, they ask you, hey, do you want to get this, do you want to get that, 30, 35, 15, 20, whatever, and it's going to be a bundle of things. And it's important that all elements are staircased, so that if you want 500 text and next month you want 700 or whatever, you can have the option. So that is a little bit the missing part of the story. And I'm not saying it works like this; it requires a lot of work, it requires the right incentives, right devices, right price, everything that I said.

Maybe just on to a specific point you were referring. We have to be competitive in each market, and the price points are different. So you were referring to slide 19, where in Netherlands with €20 you get 500 meg, that's true that in the U.K. the price point is £15 for 3 gig. So which means that we have to be in any case competitive in each market and within each market introduce these tiered pricing in order to make sure that we can have our customers consuming much more. But let's say in the different markets, and you are also referring to Italy, of course our brand, as it was advocated by Vittorio, can induce a little premium of tariffs compared to some other players, so that's why in some markets, remaining competitive, we can afford to have a slight premium.

In fairness, I was referring to only one market. Sorry, if I follow-up on that one – and it was not a shop, a price in the shop. I was referring to a price in the chart, slide 19, or page 19, where actually you basically say that you're going to charge £25 for around 500 megabytes, now.
Plus voice, plus, plus. Plus.
So how much voice you give on that one? You're not going to cannibalize voice in throwing away a lot of voice revenues just to sell data?

It's the opposite. It's not cannibalizing voice, it's immunizing our revenues. It's really immunization of revenues what we are doing. When people ask me, are you concerned about VoIP, I say today on the margin 2% is not big. Am I concerned about the future? No. Because one day we will pay 30, 35, hopefully 50, 60, 65, whatever it's going to be and we will not really care whether the call is a circuit switch call or an VoIP call, as long as we can bundle the data and the text and the SMS and whatever other service you want into one thing. So it's quite the contrary of what you are seeing. It's immunization of revenues.

Just on your EBITDA point. What I said earlier, I think it was Karen's question about a significant reduction in European margins, i.e. around 100 basis points for the full year, is entirely consistent with the adjusted operating profit range for this year. So those are precisely related. And secondly, the headline for last year at 220, the organic underlying at 190, I think at the half-year the numbers were 170 and 160. But either way, divide those by 2 and you get to around 100 basis points. So we will be down at around that sort of level for the second half of the year.
So the improvement from last year was around 20 basis points, not 50, when you basically take the organic?
It is 190 playing 160, I think. It's 160 basis points half-year organic, so it's 30.
So it's closer to 30 to 2010 to 50. Okay.
On an organic, 50 on a headline, and the guidance was on a headline.
Thanks.
I think we have a little bit of time for a few more questions if there are. Yes? Sorry, let's people who have not asked questions, so first here and then, okay. Yes?

Yes, it's Jerry Dellis here from Jefferies. Just going back to slide 41, you show a fairly interesting decline in voice traffic on European networks between Q1 and Q2. And I just wondered whether that's the start of a trend, whether it's a function maybe of your yield management work or to what extent it might just be related to perhaps slowing adoption rates of mobile broadband dongles?

And then, on the SFR slide, you talked about being open to various value maximization strategies, and I just wondered what a value maximization strategy would be potentially other than just sort of selling your stake. Thank you.
So I will take the SFR question while my colleagues try to identify the slide, because we don't.
Can you just tell us the slide?
Which slide?
Yes, sorry, it's slide 41.
You show traffic going from 115 to 88.
That's the year-on-year growth.
That's the year-on-year growth of data. It's year-on-year growth of total number of petabytes that Steve carries. So it's not a decline. It's a slowing down of the acceleration.

No, no. I'm not suggesting it's not a strong number, but it is nevertheless quite a slowdown. I seem to remember six months ago you presented a chart where you talked about 70 or 71% growth in data traffic across Europe for the full year, so I'm just wondering whether we are seeing that as your yield management kicks in, we may be seeing traffic slow a little bit.
Yes.

I think the correct answer to that is yes, particularly if you consider most of the traffic growth is video and then that's the thing that one has to really focus on is video. Sometimes it's streaming audio, and we particularly told you the techniques to manage video in the infrastructure we put in.
When one can free space, where we have very high usage in mobile broadband and which thanks to those techniques have been managed. So that's where we have had strong slowdown.

And, again, it's linked to the commercial question which was asked before. On SFR, we look at various options. There are options; some are more appealing, some are less appealing and again we are open to all of them. But what I wanted to say is, we are open and there is not a single one option, or we are not a forced seller, if you want to put it in journalistic terms. There were questions. Let me see, somebody who has not already, let's give opportunities to all. Yes, there, and then I go back there. And yes?

Yes, thank you. It's Guy Peddy from Macquarie. Two quick questions. As you've reviewed the first half results, did you consider actually reinvesting some of your strength that you're going to have in margins in the second half in restimulating the revenue growth and market share even more so, so actually continuing to invest more in margin?

And then on a secondary point, is your CapEx – it seems like your CapEx outlook is a little bit vaguer than perhaps it was. Is that a function of the fact you don't have spectrum visibility in most of your European markets and therefore how you plan your networks on a five year view is still open to various different options? Thank you.

Our CapEx outlook does not include spectrum costs, so we take spectrum costs out. And in that respect, yes, you are right, we don't have visibility because there will be auctions in the U.K. and Spain, later in the following year possibly in Italy, and you don't know where the auctions can go because it depends on how many people will participate and so. But it's not part of our CapEx thing.

I want to reiterate this CapEx point because I don't think we have been vague. I think Michel has said we were at 11% last year, we will be in around that this year, and we feel that's the right amount of investment. What I said is I am not particularly fixated with the specific percentage; I'm much more fixated in free cash flow and return to shareholders. And then we can manage the different plans of the P&L according to the needs. So that was my meaning. Having said that, I think Michel was more precise than me, as it often is the case, in saying we will be around where we were last year.

On reinvesting the margin, we had a discussion and every time, three to four times per year, we have our forecasting. We look at how things are going, it's always a balanced judgment of how much more resources you want to put in the market and how much is the risk of heating up commercially every market. In some conditions, I mean, Italy was a case we have been dragged into a strong competition in the spring. I said we will not refrain from competing. I always repeat we do not refrain from competing. In other cases we just manage in a financially disciplined way commercial growth. I cannot give you a generalized answer.
I think we are – we can probably take one or two more maximum? No, no, only one. Okay. You have been so patient in waiting, I think you deserve the last slot.

Thank you. It's John Davies here from ING. I'm going to push it and ask two questions. First of all, historically, when you had simultaneously a revenue growth target and an EBITDA target, there was some cause for arguing that your competitors therefore had a good insight into exactly what you were going to do and it's operated somewhat as a straitjacket on your operational flexibility. And that was something you moved away from. You've gone back to that now. Is that a change of mind as to what your competitors are thinking or is it a sending of a message to them as to where the market should be going?
And the second one is one I think for Steve. What's the thinking on voice on LTE in terms of standards and so forth at the moment? Thank you.

Yes, the first part of your question, we have here Rosemary, who is our General Council, has only one answer. Since signaling is not legal, by definition it's not signaling, and it is a commitment. What can I say? We are convinced that things are going in the right direction. What can I say? We have more – I would say we are more sure about the economics of data. I think that going back to the earlier remark, all the things that I have been talking about from when I was Head of Europe to more recently on the network and capacity management side, we are now seeing the results through, and we start seeing, as I said, positive ARPU reactions on the data front.
So it's early days. We cannot to be super aggressive which is why we have a range, but things are going in the right direction, and absolutely there is no signaling element in anything we say.

I'll do the second one. The voice over LTE is something that we pioneered with good collaboration with Verizon and China Mobile. We progressed it to a de facto standard that I'm now pleased to tell you is becoming the industry standard and it's going through the – the standards body is to be ratified now. So it's a very good example of collaboration between the three of us that's now become the industry standard, and that's going through as we speak.
Very good. I thank you very much for your attention and for your questions. And again, thank you very much for coming today.
